tldr: The sodium-sulfur battery is a promising energy storage solution due to its high energy density and potential for cost reduction. The battery uses a solid ceramic electrolyte and operates at temperatures between 300 and 400°C. Development efforts are focused on improving reliability, cost, and performance, as well as addressing safety and application engineering aspects. The central sodium-sulfur cell design offers advantages in terms of corrosion resistance and ease of sulfur containment.
